title: 105_hr2184
content:
The Act titled "Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997" is cited as the short title. Private security officers in the United States are growing rapidly and function as an adjunct to public law enforcement. The industry provides opportunities for entry-level job applicants and protects individuals and various properties such as banks, hospitals, and airports. Private security officers in the United States are increasingly supplementing sworn law enforcement officers in providing services to the public. With the rise of private shopping malls, individuals are more likely to interact with private security personnel than with public law enforcement officers. This trend has accelerated as the number of public sector law enforcement officers has decreased, serving important public policy goals. Private security officers in the United States are becoming more prevalent in providing services to the public. The public struggles to differentiate between private security personnel and sworn law enforcement officers. The American public supports the use of well-trained private security personnel as a supplement, not a replacement, for law enforcement officers. Screening for private security officers, especially those carrying weapons, should be thorough. SEC. 3. BACKGROUND CHECKS. At the request of an employer or association, fingerprints or other identification methods must be submitted to the Attorney General for background checks on private security officers. The Attorney General will search criminal records and provide results within 30 days. The Attorney General encourages the use of technology for compiling criminal history information. Associations must submit employee fingerprints for processing within one business day. They also need to transfer identification and criminal history records to employers promptly. Associations must provide copies to licensing authorities for requests made on behalf of employers. The Attorney General may prescribe regulations for the transfer of identification and criminal history records to employers. The report on inquiries made by employers must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary after 2 years. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends section 534 of title 28, US Code to include private security officer background checks by designated employer associations.

SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY. Imposes fines or imprisonment for misuse of information obtained under section 3 for private security officer employment purposes.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. Addresses employer liability issues. SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. Employers relying on Attorney General's criminal history info for employment decisions are not liable for damages. The Act defines key terms such as "Attorney General," "employee," "employer," "fingerprint," and "private security officer." The term "private security officer" refers to an individual who provides security services for compensation, whether armed or unarmed, in uniform or plain clothes. This definition excludes sworn police officers with law enforcement powers, licensed professionals, internal auditors, and individuals whose duties are not primarily security-related. The term "security services" refers to the observation or reporting of intrusion, larceny, vandalism, fire, or trespass by individuals such as shoplifters, trespassers, military personnel, electronic security system employees, prison transport staff, and armored vehicle company employees. The term "security services" includes deterrence of theft, observation of unlawful activity, protection of individuals and property, control of access to premises, maintenance of order at public activities, and provision of canine services for detecting unlawful substances. The term "State" refers to various regions including States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 8. USER FEES. The Attorney General may collect user fees for requests for criminal history information. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act will be effective on July 1, 1999.
